title: Brian Viner reviews The Day Shall Come
text:
The Day Shall Come

Rating:

Verdict: A Morris minor

Chris Morris, the ferocious satirist behind TV shows such as Brass Eye and The Day Today, made his directorial debut with Four Lions in 2010 - a wickedly funny and provocative comedy about four hapless British jihadis.

With The Day Shall Come, Morris wades back into similar territory, except that the would-be terrorist is entirely harmless

With The Day Shall Come, Morris wades back into similar territory, except that the would-be terrorist is entirely harmless.

He is Moses (Marchant Davis), an African-American living in Miami, Florida, with revolutionary delusions and wobbly mental health.

This makes him the perfect target for corrupt FBI officers, who use their resources to set up him and his associates as a major threat to homeland security, purely to enhance their own reputations.

He is Moses (Marchant Davis), an African-American living in Miami, Florida, with revolutionary delusions and wobbly mental health

Morris claims to have based all this on at least ‘100 true stories’, which may well be the case, but it’s a shame his film isn’t funnier.

There are some great lines, and fine performances all round, notably by Davis, and the ever-reliable Anna Kendrick as the FBI agent leading the operation.

But with fond memories of Four Lions and a healthy respect for Morris’s savage irreverence, I expected to laugh like a drain. Instead, it was just an occasional gurgle.
